#Text=India seeks web crackdown after failed talks with industry
#Text=Tuesday , December 6 , 2011
#Text=Indian authorities today declared an intent to force web companies to screen content for " offensive " and " blasphemous material " .

column1: #Text=The move follows failed talks yesterday with Facebook , Google , Yahoo ! , and Microsoft .
#Text=Kapil Sibal at the 2007 World Economic Forum .
#Text=Image : World Economic Forum .

#Text=Communications Minister Kapil Sibal says " My aim is that insulting material never gets uploaded " , and that web firms " will have to give us the data , where these images are being uploaded and who is doing it . "
#Text=The government 's planned new policy is in response to web-based firms informing him they could not prevent such material being uploaded . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=They have given it to me in writing that they will not do anything until we get an order from the court ,  even though " At a meeting on 4 November , we showed them some of the photos and they too agreed that the photos were offensive , " said Sibal .

#Text=Sibal calls the situation  unacceptable " and disputes the firms ' defence of being merely " platforms " for others to add material .

column1: #Text=He claims they showed their " intention was not to cooperate " .
#Text=Facebook promised ongoing dialogue in a statement and " [ recognise ] the government 's interest in minimising the amount of abusive content " .

column1: #Text=Google say they remove material breaching their policies and to comply with local legislation . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=But when content is legal and does n't violate our policies , we wo n't remove it just because it 's controversial , as we believe that people 's differing views , so long as they 're legal , should be respected and protected ,  the company added .

#Text=A response from web firms of  we throw up our hands , we ca n't do anything about this " would not be tolerated .

column1: #Text=Although some reports suggest the spat has been triggered by critiques of powerful politician Sonia Gandhi , Sibal claims the firms have previously hesitated to respond to requests for details of " terrorists " .
#Text=All the material the government wishes to censor is " absolutely illegal , defamatory , pornographic or other similar kind of material " says Congress spokesman Abhishek Manu Singhvi .
#Text=Material in question includes cartoons of Gandhi and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and material mocking religion including an image depicting pigs in Mecca .
#Text=The dispute is believed to stem from material against Sonia Gandhi , pictured here in 2007 .
#Text=Image : Agência Brasil .
#Text=Indian computer security expert Vijay Mukhi rubbished the suggestions .
#Text=" The idea of prescreening is impossible .
